resource.chars:
I have but little to add respecting the district
of Gneiss lying to the west of the line from Loch
Eribol to the head of Loch Maree, & which should probably be continued to Loch Carron throughout
which the <s>dip<\s> strike, as far as has been observed is about
North West. The Gneiss is only seen at intervals
between which it is covered up by Old Red Sandstone
so that we cannot <s>obtain<\s> <s>get<\s> see any <s>good<\s> continuous
section, <s>across<\s> nor obtain a good idea of the relations
of the different masses to each other. There
seem to be a succession of arches of moderate
diameter, of which we see the perpendicular
walls standing out in relief, while the central
parts between being lower are covered by the
Sandstone. It will be seen <s>by<\s> on the map that
the Gneiss is vertical both at Cape Wrath, at Sandwood
Bay 5 miles south of that Cape, again vertical
at Loch Inchard, on both sides of Storr Point
& on the north side of Loch Maree; all with
a strike <s>of nearly<\s> between N45W &  N25W. I found
the same direction <s>of<\s> in the Gneiss of the Isle
of Lewis as far as I examined it: there is a
vertical plane crossing the Island N45W from
Broad Bay near Stornaway to Barvas; on the
south side of which is a broad arch which I
only followed partially; it's central axis is seen
at Callernish striking N20W, so that it's other
boundary may be looked for towards the southern
end of Lewis.
